nodes.bodyText: Are these two cases exclusive?
Yes, this is part of oneof as mentioned here
You can define an abstract getLogger()  in SslContextProvider, then you will not be using different loggers for different methods.

I understand the suggestion but is that pattern being used elsewhere in grpc/xds? With the current pattern any method will always use the logger of the class where the method is defined instead of the logger of the deepest subclass. Since the fully qualified method name in the log output is always that of the method's own class wouldn't it be useful to also have the logger of that class?
Good point. Also the current pattern in this PR is the same as what is being used elsewhere.
Seems callback always comes with an executor. Is it possible to add getExecutor() method to Callback instead of defining CallbackPair?
yes, good idea. Done
nit: @VisibleForTesting.
done
Why invoking callback here requires the lock while it doesn't in addCallback?

The if clause on line 107 does not require the lock

That is what I am concerning. You are holding the lock to perform the callback here. But in addCallback it does not. This means at least one case is wrong. If invoking the callback requires synchronization (that's very suspicious), the one in addCallback also needs to do so. If the callback does not need synchronization, a concurrent list here is sufficient.

@voidzcy the lock is for the pendingCallbacks list only and not for the actual callback. When addCallback is called and there is an sslContext available then callback is called with that sslContext (as sslContextCopy). Otherwise addCallback and makePendingCallbacks have to synchronize on pendingCallbacks
Then you don't need to hold the lock while invoking the callback, just make pendingCallbacks a concurrent list.

That's a good point but I don't know if it's worth making the change/improvement. The list is unlikely to be longer than 1 or 2 elements (after the callbacks it is cleared) and the callbacks are into our own code (never user provided callbacks). Also by "concurrent list" did you mean CopyOnWriteArrayList?
I was just being abstract of saying "concurrent list". But, realistically CopyOnWriteArrayList is an overkill. I suspect ArrayBlockingQueue would be enough.
I addressed this comment by making a copy of the list for invoking the callback so there is no lock held when the callbacks are made. Using ArrayBlockingQueue wouldn't work here BTW.
Why a blocking queue does not work? I don't see any get/insert-to-middle operations needed.

The pendingCallbacks is only needed to hold the "pending callbacks" until an sslContext is built and appropriate locks should be in place to ensure there is no race between checking/updating of pendingCallbacks and sslContext (like the latest fix made).
I don't see the need for either blocking or queue aspect of the blocking queue.
I mean using a blocking data structure is way better than your current approach (aka, acquire the lock, make a copy, etc). It's more efficient and elegant in terms of code maintainability.
The exception handling doesn't seem to be right, exceptions just go into a black hole.
good catch. Fixed.

Throwing such an exception here seem to be too late, and it's somewhat misleading. Callers of updateCertificate() and updateTrustedRoots() will never be the cause of this class being in invalid state. Instead, you should perform the check in the constructor.
good point. fixed
Can savedKey be null? I think it's not required for client ssl context builder. Just not sure if it's true for MTLS.

It can be proved that savedKey can't be null at this point:

CertProviderSslContextProvider.updateSslContextWhenReady is where it all starts. And in case of isMtls() and savedKey != null it calls
DynamicSslContextProvider.updateSslContext which calls CertProviderClientSslContextProvider.getSslContextBuilder  - this code.

In case this SslContextProvider is set up for mTLS (as dictated by xDS) then the SslContextBuilder is supplied with savedKey when available.
So this method is only called by DynamicSslContextProvider.updateSslContext not at will (which should be mention in javadoc), so the signature here should be protected rather than public.

Correct. In DynamicSslContextProvider it is defined as
 protected abstract SslContextBuilder getSslContextBuilder

But over here the visibility was increased to public (by mistake). I'll fix that.
Changed to protected final like all the other subclasses.
savedKey and savedCertChain are very likely null all the time, because even they are set by updateCertificate(),  updateCertificate() may  immediately and automatically trigger clearKeysAndCerts().

Note that the saved* values are used to generate the sslContext and after that all the saved* fields are set to null. So you are right most of the time the saved* values are null but sslContext will be non-null (if it has been generated once) which is what is needed by all the consumers of this class.
The reason for setting the saved* values to null is because of the separate calls updateCertificate and updateTrustedRoots from the CertificateProvider. I can build an SslContext for a given state (mTLS, clientTls or serverTls) only when all the values are in. Without assuming any order for updateCertificate and updateTrustedRoots calls the best (and only?) way to do this is to check for the required saved* values to be non-null and setting them to null (after building the sslContext) for the next cycle of updateCertificate and updateTrustedRoots.
How is sslContext synchronized between updateSslContext () and addCallback()? Are updateSslContext () and addCallback() run in the same thread or they are executed sequentially?

No, they don't have to be sequential or from the same thread. I guess I could have used AtomicReference because all I need is atomic accesses to sslContext but instead I used sslContextCopy (local copy) in both updateSslContext () and addCallback() like this:
    SslContext sslContextCopy = sslContext;
   ... use sslContextCopy from here...

because reference assignments are atomic.

There could still be data race:
(1) addCallback() checks sslContext, and it's null.
(2) then updateSslContext () set sslContext and drains penddingCallbacks
(3) then addCallback() adds a callback to penddingCallbacks and it's never performed.
nit: s/localexecutor/localExecutor/g
good catch, removed the var altogether
This method still needs synchronized (pendingCallbacks) because onError() is calling it, and need be synchronized with addCallback().
done
